content: If the government was formed to represent the interests of it's people; Why do corporations get better representation in our government? Despite all of OUR future tax dollars the only group that is benefiting from the bailouts are the executives of the bailed out corporations... So while the corporations are saved from bankruptcy, 1 in 10 Americans which comprise the labor behind those companies are now on food stamps and losing their homes. Since when should a corporation get better representation in our government than "we the people"?
reply: If the government was formed to represent the interests of it's people; Why do corporations get better representation in our government? title: Why do corporations get better representation in our government?

content: Because the donate the most money to the politicians, simple as that. As we and the Tea Party's have been saying, WE the People need to take back our country. Get rid of all the corrupt politicians and clean house. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

title: Why do corporations get better representation in our government?

content: quote: Originally posted by 21031127: Despite all of OUR future tax dollars the only group that is benefiting from the bailouts are the executives of the bailed out corporations... So while the corporations are saved from bankruptcy, 1 in 10 Americans which comprise the labor behind those companies are now on food stamps and losing their homes. Since when should a corporation get better representation in our government than "we the people"? Well, just to play devil's advocate... The majority of taxes in government coffers were put there by the rich (the $250k+ wageearners) and corporations. So, they SHOULD reap the greatest reward, unless you are proposing we adopt a socialist or communist style of government. The lower class puts virtually nothing into the federal government and the middle class puts very little, yet they already reap the greatest rewards in terms of services they receive. The tax burden, apportioned by economic class, isn't as unfair as you think it is... In addition, true, 1 in 10 of the workers who made those corporations successful are now on unemployment. Well, it's possible that without a bailout it could be 2 in 10.
quote: Originally posted by 21031127: Despite all of OUR future tax dollars the only group that is benefiting from the bailouts are the executives of the bailed out corporations... So while the corporations are saved from bankruptcy, 1 in 10 Americans which comprise the labor behind those companies are now on food stamps and losing their homes. Since when should a corporation get better representation in our government than "we the people"?

So, they SHOULD reap the greatest reward, unless you are proposing we adopt a socialist or communist style of government. The lower class puts virtually nothing into the federal government and the middle class puts very little, yet they already reap the greatest rewards in terms of services they receive. The tax burden, apportioned by economic class, isn't as unfair as you think it is... In addition, true, 1 in 10 of the workers who made those corporations successful are now on unemployment. Well, it's possible that without a bailout it could be 2 in 10.
